snippet.textDisplay: Sudden loss is hard. I've lost my Dad last year to a sudden stroke/heart attack. I was in a different town when it happened and only saw him at the funeral. We spent our time together mostly when he drove me around and rarely meet when I was at home. I couldn't deny I still have questions about how exactly he went and the mysteries are just not helping me to grieve easier.
snippet.textOriginal: Sudden loss is hard. I've lost my Dad last year to a sudden stroke/heart attack. I was in a different town when it happened and only saw him at the funeral. We spent our time together mostly when he drove me around and rarely meet when I was at home. I couldn't deny I still have questions about how exactly he went and the mysteries are just not helping me to grieve easier.

snippet.textDisplay: For NTSB defense, they have been suggested a lot of improvement on helicopter safety but they do not have the power to force the industry to make that change.  It is the FAA who change and enforce the standard.  Based on the statement from the FAA, the reason they never implemented the suggestion from the NTSB was it is not cost effective to do so.  Seeing what happened to the 737 Max, it is hugely possible the FAA have been pocketing money from the aerial industry to soften the standard.  The anger should be directed to the FAA, not the NTSB.
snippet.textOriginal: For NTSB defense, they have been suggested a lot of improvement on helicopter safety but they do not have the power to force the industry to make that change.  It is the FAA who change and enforce the standard.  Based on the statement from the FAA, the reason they never implemented the suggestion from the NTSB was it is not cost effective to do so.  Seeing what happened to the 737 Max, it is hugely possible the FAA have been pocketing money from the aerial industry to soften the standard.  The anger should be directed to the FAA, not the NTSB.

He's mentioned it before, but I think this is the first time on his show he's gone into so much detail about his families tragedy. You can tell it pains him ~40 years later. snippet.textDisplay:
Oh, can I relate.  It´s simply unconceivable to lose your closest loved ones to a sudden plane-, helicopter- or car crash.
I went through such tragedies TWICE.
RIP my beautiful Baby girl   AND   a few years later …. my way too young husband.
These pains of sudden losses will never fade.
Stephen and Jon, thank you. Your words are full of compassion, understanding and dignity
(Indeed, unfortunately only those who also went through such disasters can REALLY relate!)
snippet.textOriginal:
*Oh, can I relate.*  It´s simply *unconceivable* to lose your closest loved ones to a sudden plane-, helicopter- or car crash. 
I went through such tragedies TWICE. 
*RIP* my beautiful Baby girl   AND   a few years later …. my way too young husband. 
These pains of sudden losses will never fade. 
*Stephen and Jon, thank you. Your words are full of compassion, understanding and dignity*
(Indeed, unfortunately only those who also went through such disasters can REALLY relate!)

snippet.textDisplay: On your own suggestion, I've stopped watching you about a half a year ago, taking to heart what you and (a/your?) priest had understood in parable/lore that the only humor/laughter that the devil (our baser instincts) can't abide or withstand is joy (not ridicule, schadenfreude, sarcasm, insult, etc.).  Comedy in drama and performance certainly calls attention, brings amusement, facilitates understanding and acceptance of awkward points. You are a top rated entertainer on an expensive rented stage with 200 staffers in mutual support. I only meant to change my easy amusement because the simple depth of the proposition moved me. Kobe was  a uniquely powerful persona and his loved daughter lit up people that she didn't even know were watching. Ms. Mauser, the Altobellis and Checters and the pilot Mr. Zobayan, to me are that great loss when people who care and serve and raise up the future must relinquish.You and John (who also shows magnificent humanity on his choices, arrangements and performances on his albums) have (along with Rachel Nichols sincerity and touch, hosting The Jump) should be acclaimed for this segment. Thank you for sharing your close experience and insight. I will look to promote Eye In The Sky and similar Sterile Cockpit protocols, investigation tools and protections. Thank you for pronouncing the names of all that were lost in the crash.
snippet.textOriginal: On your own suggestion, I've stopped watching you about a half a year ago, taking to heart what you and (a/your?) priest had understood in parable/lore that the only humor/laughter that the devil (our baser instincts) can't abide or withstand is joy (not ridicule, schadenfreude, sarcasm, insult, etc.).  Comedy in drama and performance certainly calls attention, brings amusement, facilitates understanding and acceptance of awkward points. You are a top rated entertainer on an expensive rented stage with 200 staffers in mutual support. I only meant to change my easy amusement because the simple depth of the proposition moved me. Kobe was  a uniquely powerful persona and his loved daughter lit up people that she didn't even know were watching. Ms. Mauser, the Altobellis and Checters and the pilot Mr. Zobayan, to me are that great loss when people who care and serve and raise up the future must relinquish.You and John (who also shows magnificent humanity on his choices, arrangements and performances on his albums) have (along with Rachel Nichols sincerity and touch, hosting The Jump) should be acclaimed for this segment. Thank you for sharing your close experience and insight. I will look to promote Eye In The Sky and similar Sterile Cockpit protocols, investigation tools and protections. Thank you for pronouncing the names of all that were lost in the crash.

snippet.textDisplay:
Oh for the love of.
So Colbert admits he did not know Bryant. And he mentions his father and two closest (years) brothers died in a plane crash almost 50 years ago. There have been LOTS of deadly airlines/helicopter crashes since he took over the Late Show. So why is he mentioning the crash of his family especially now?
Simple.
Great for ratings...beginning and end. He didn't bother using his past tragedy until a BIG NAME died in an aircraft crash...than he could trundle it out to use and get a HUGE response.
Of course, you people just lapped it up...EXACTLY the reaction he was counting on.
Man you people are gullible.

 Simple.

 Of course, you people just lapped it up...EXACTLY the reaction he was counting on.

snippet.textDisplay: I didn't know the he'd lost his father and two brothers in a crash. That's heartbreaking. My heart is breaking for the people who are mourning this loss of Kobe, his daughter and the others who died in this crash. I'm not a sports fan by any stretch of the imagination, but I am a child, a mother, a grandmother, a niece, an aunt and most of all a human being. I have never lost a child, but I have lost my dad, my husband, my great niece, my favorite nephew that was more like a son and a slew of other family and friends. The only pain I can't feel for these people is the loss of a child. I can't knew what Kobe's wife is feeling having lost her daughter or what the other parents are feeling and I'm thankful for that. I cried when I learned that they had just had another child in June. That baby girl will never have a chance to know the great man that was her father. That's beyond sad because she truly had a great, loving father. Idk if these other people had children or not because I can't deal with that much sadness so I'm avoiding knowing those things. Please continue to pray for these people in whatever way you pray and if your coming m get the chance please show them some love and support. Oh just show whoever you're around some extra love and support. You never know when that chance will be gone.

The only pain I can't feel for these people is the loss of a child. I can't knew what Kobe's wife is feeling having lost her daughter or what the other parents are feeling and I'm thankful for that. I cried when I learned that they had just had another child in June. That baby girl will never have a chance to know the great man that was her father. That's beyond sad because she truly had a great, loving father. Idk if these other people had children or not because I can't deal with that much sadness so I'm avoiding knowing those things. Please continue to pray for these people in whatever way you pray and if your coming m get the chance please show them some love and support. Oh just show whoever you're around some extra love and support. You never know when that chance will be gone.

snippet.textDisplay:
You're possibly the first to pay tribute to ALL those who lost their lives in that tragic event. For the last few days news and raido channels have been labeling it as the "Kobe Bryant Crash" and while they talk about how sad it was for the Bryant's to lose two of their family members, they don't even make an effort to mention the others.

John Altobelli, Keri Altobelli and Alyssa Altobelli

Christina Mauser

Ara Zobayan

Sarah Chester and Payton Chester

They weren't famous but they had names and they mattered. Kudos to you Mr. Colbert.

snippet.textDisplay: I lost my real father when I was 11.  I write "real" because I was raised by my stepfather who adopted me after marrying my mom.  He was an over the road trucker.  I often thought of him and asked my mom about him until the day we got a phone call from his sister informing us that he died in a truck accident.  I still remember trying not to cry and running out of the kitchen.  My sister came to me and held me as I cried.  I'm trying not to cry as I'm typing this right now.
snippet.textOriginal: I lost my real father when I was 11.  I write "real" because I was raised by my stepfather who adopted me after marrying my mom.  He was an over the road trucker.  I often thought of him and asked my mom about him until the day we got a phone call from his sister informing us that he died in a truck accident.  I still remember trying not to cry and running out of the kitchen.  My sister came to me and held me as I cried.  I'm trying not to cry as I'm typing this right now.

snippet.textDisplay: I 100% agree with Colbert. Helicopters should have the same on-board data technology requirements across all airframes to find the root cause of incidents in order to improve overall flight safety and reduce the risk of fatality and destruction. As a retired military ground and aviation safety manager/investigator, I can’t help but feel as though one of the primary factors may very well be the pilot’s decision to fly in those conditions - even with the clearance, pilot’s experience/rating, and capabilities of the helicopter. It’s one thing to operate an aircraft as an instrument-rated pilot in an instrument-rated aircraft in IMC conditions but in a helicopter is an entirely different animal. Maybe some new requirements will come of this, of course the FAA has long been reluctant to implement CVR/FDR requirements even with NTSB recommendations for some reason; the ball has always been and will be in the FAA’s court to make changes. God bless those lost and the families they leave behind.
snippet.textOriginal: I 100% agree with Colbert. Helicopters should have the same on-board data technology requirements across all airframes to find the root cause of incidents in order to improve overall flight safety and reduce the risk of fatality and destruction. As a retired military ground and aviation safety manager/investigator, I can’t help but feel as though one of the primary factors may very well be the pilot’s decision to fly in those conditions - even with the clearance, pilot’s experience/rating, and capabilities of the helicopter. It’s one thing to operate an aircraft as an instrument-rated pilot in an instrument-rated aircraft in IMC conditions but in a helicopter is an entirely different animal. Maybe some new requirements will come of this, of course the FAA has long been reluctant to implement CVR/FDR requirements even with NTSB recommendations for some reason; the ball has always been and will be in the FAA’s court to make changes. God bless those lost and the families they leave behind.

snippet.textDisplay: Stephen. not that you will see this but. Some helicopters do have black boxes. I tragically lost my Step Dad in the July 4th crash in the Bahamas with the WV billionaire. Their helicopter DID have a black box which was recovered. But it doesn't make anything easier. We are 7 months on with no info on why it happened.  Even when we do find out what the black box data says it still won't make it easier.
snippet.textOriginal: Stephen. not that you will see this but. Some helicopters do have black boxes. I tragically lost my Step Dad in the July 4th crash in the Bahamas with the WV billionaire. Their helicopter DID have a black box which was recovered. But it doesn't make anything easier. We are 7 months on with no info on why it happened.  Even when we do find out what the black box data says it still won't make it easier.

snippet.textDisplay: Stephen the NTSB has said they've recommended the FAA to require black boxes and TAS devices on these type of choppers precisely because there's been other accidents that have happened where other choppers didn't have a black box or TAS but the FAA never did anything about it, so the NTSB had to close out their recommendations.
snippet.textOriginal: Stephen the NTSB has said they've recommended the FAA to require black boxes and TAS devices on these type of choppers precisely because there's been other accidents that have happened where other choppers didn't have a black box or TAS but the FAA never did anything about it, so the NTSB had to close out their recommendations.

snippet.textDisplay: I used to work for Boeing as an assembly mechanic and am somewhat familiar with the black boxes (which are actually florescent orange) Those boxes are very highly engineered and cost a HUGE amount of money for the two recorders. It would probably add 10% to 20% to the cost of the helicopter to add them. No kidding, they are that expensive.
snippet.textOriginal: I used to work for Boeing as an assembly mechanic and am somewhat familiar with the black boxes (which are actually florescent orange) Those boxes are very highly engineered and cost a HUGE amount of money for the two recorders.
